DOC.HEAD: Despite Dangers, Convoys Brave Romanian Route
Eds: SUBS grafs 3, 6 to CORRECT to Ceausescu sted Ceauescu; pickup 7th graf pvs, `Hungarian radio...'
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The bent old woman, head scarved and feet clad in clumsy felt slippers against the cold, smiled toothlessly as she surveyed the ragtag relief convoy of cars, vans and taxis loaded with supplies. ``There is an old Romanian saying: `First servings for everyone else, last dregs for the Romanians,' she exclaimed. ``Now that the devil is dead, maybe that will change.'' Toppled and executed, President Nicolae Ceausescu remains ``Dracul'' _ the Devil _ to many who suffered under his hard hand for 24 years. As the army tries to crush die-hard units of his special police, humanitarian aid is pouring in from abroad. Scores of hastily organized convoys with Hungarians, Germans, Americans, Brits and Belgians behind the wheel have braved poor roads and the threat of ambush to help, assembling in neighboring Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Hungary and then heading for the border. Several aid volunteers have been reported killed or wounded by Ceausescu's henchmen. Hungarian radio said Thursday that close to 1,000 trucks and countless autos made the dangerous trek from Hungary alone since Dec. 22. Typical was a 16-vehicle convoy assembled early one morning by the Free Democratic Party of Hungary. Some highlights of its 16-hour voyage betweeen Budapest, the Hungarian capital, and Timisoara, Romania, 300 miles to the southeast: _ Budapest, 2:12 a.m. Wednesday. As the convoy forms, Jozsef Kovacs, who helped put together the shipment of food, clothing and medicine, relates the case of a driver in another convoy, shot in Timisoara by a member of Ceausescu's Securitate police posing as a hospital worker. Faces turn glum and one volunteer begs off. _ Varsand, Romania, 9:20 a.m. Processing of entry papers comes to a halt as border guards and other Romanians crowd to watch the videotaped trial of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. As the 71-year-old dictator grimaces, a woman in a fur hat hisses: ``Ah, the devil.'' Others laugh and nudge each other. _ Varsand, 11:30 a.m. A grinning man hoists a hand in a victory sign. Hundreds of others follow suit along the route, including children, old women and peasants on horse-drawn carriages. ``God has sent you!,'' yells one woman. ``Victory!,'' cries another. _ On the road to Zindanu Nou, 11:40 a.m. Two smiling soldiers armed with machine guns loom from the white fog _ the first of numerous road checks. A three-mile line of cars waits for service at two gas pumps, but there are smiles and waves to the passing caravan with Red Cross emblems displayed on car hoods and fluttering from antennae. _ Zindanu Nou, 12:30 p.m. Not everyone is happy in the village. A neighbor of the old woman with the toothless grin waves down one of the cars in the caravan and pleads for bandages, sobbing that her husband, a recent amputee, has been dismissed from hospital for lack of space. _ Arad, 1:07 p.m. A man drops his bicycle to blow kisses as the convoy enters the city, the site of heavy fighting just days before. Romanian flags, their Communist emblems cut from the middle, flutter from hundreds of buildings. While some volunteers help unload medical supplies, others visit a post-surgical ward. _ Ortisoara, 1:57 p.m. A boy no more than 7 years old, a toy machine gun slung over his shoulder, waves a Romanian flag and makes the V sign as the convoy moves by. _ Timisoara, 2:12 p.m. Much of the convoy's goods have disappeared inside a main depot at the city's Central Hospital, but some non-medical supplies _ bread, tinned goods, powdered soup _ are spread out on the front lawn for the taking. Several young soldiers, rifles slung, are busy helping themselves. John Haydok, a Hungarian who now lives in Yonkers, N.Y., is tired but happy. The 42-year-old man temporarily shut his land developing business to help here. ``This is my first convoy,'' he says, beaming and wiping his brow. ``I'm sure it won't be my last.''
